\u003Cp\u003EAbove Treeline is the highest of the three elevation bands used in the SAC advisories. It includes alpine areas where the most snow falls and the winds are the strongest. It is not an exact elevation, but a characteristic of the terrain, beginning as the treeline transitions into open slopes extending to ridges and the tops of the highest peaks.\u003C\/p\u003E\n ","list":["trigger","shrinkToFit"]},"beautytips_manager_custom_4":{"cssSelect":"p#mid-rating-info","style":"default","trigger":["click","click"],"shrinkToFit":false,"ajaxDisableLink":false,"text":" \u003Cp\u003ENear Treeline is the middle of the three elevation bands used in the SAC advisories. It is a transition zone between dense forests and treeless alpine areas. It is the narrowest of the three elevation bands, extending only a few hundred feet above and below the treeline. It varies locally, and is not a constant elevation or width.\u003C\/p\u003E\n ","list":["trigger","shrinkToFit"]},"beautytips_manager_custom_5":{"cssSelect":"p#lower-rating-info","style":"default","trigger":["click","click"],"shrinkToFit":false,"ajaxDisableLink":false,"text":" \u003Cp\u003EBelow Treeline is the lowest of three elevation bands used in the SAC advisories. Tree cover shelters the snow from wind effects.\u003C\/p\u003E\n ","list":["trigger","shrinkToFit"]},"beautytips_manager_custom_6":{"cssSelect":"span#likelihood-info","style":"default","trigger":["click","click"],"shrinkToFit":false,"ajaxDisableLink":false,"text":" \u003Cp\u003ELikelihood is a description of the chance of encountering a particular \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eavalanche\u003C\/a\u003E problem. It combines the spatial distribution of the problem and the sensitivity or ease of triggering an \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eavalanche\u003C\/a\u003E. The spatial distribution indicates how likely you are to encounter the problem in the highlighted \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eavalanche\u003C\/a\u003E terrain. The sensitive indicates how easy it is to \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/trigger\u0022 title=\u0022A disturbance that initiates fracture within the weak layer causing an avalanche. Sensitivity includes both natural or spontaneous release and human \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/trigger\u0022 title=\u0022A disturbance that initiates fracture within the weak layer causing an avalanche. In 90 percent of avalanche accidents, the victim or someone in the victims party triggers the avalanche.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Etriggered\u003C\/a\u003E \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eavalanches\u003C\/a\u003E.\u003C\/p\u003E\n ","list":["trigger","shrinkToFit"]},"beautytips_manager_custom_7":{"cssSelect":"span#size-info","style":"default","trigger":["click","click"],"shrinkToFit":false,"ajaxDisableLink":false,"text":" \u003Cp\u003ESize is based on the destructive potential of \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eavalanches\u003C\/a\u003E. SMALL (\u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/d1\u0022 title=\u0022Relatively harmless to people.\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003ED1\u003C\/a\u003E) \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eavalanches\u003C\/a\u003E are relatively harmless to people unless they push you into a \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/terrain-trap\u0022 title=\u0022Terrain in which the consequences of an avalanche are especially hazardous, such as a gully, an abrupt transition, an avalanche path that terminates in trees, a crevasse field or a cliff.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eterrain trap\u003C\/a\u003E. LARGE (\u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/d2\u0022 title=\u0022Could bury, injure, or kill a person.\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003ED2\u003C\/a\u003E) \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eavalanches\u003C\/a\u003E could bury, injure or kill a person. VERY LARGE (\u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/d3\u0022 title=\u0022Could bury and destroy a car, damage a truck, destroy a wood frame house, or break a few trees.\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003ED3\u003C\/a\u003E) \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eavalanches\u003C\/a\u003E could bury cars, destroy a house, or break trees. HISTORIC (\u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/d4\u0022 title=\u0022Could destroy a railway car, large truck, several buildings, or a substantial amount of forest.\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003ED4\u003C\/a\u003E \u0026amp;\u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/d5\u0022 title=\u0022Could gouge the landscape. Largest snow avalanche known.\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003ED5\u003C\/a\u003E) \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eavalanches\u003C\/a\u003E are even more destructive, nearing the maximum size the slope could produce and could destroy all or part of a small town.\u003C\/p\u003E\n ","list":["trigger","shrinkToFit"]},"beautytips_manager_custom_8":{"cssSelect":"span#trend-info","style":"default","trigger":["click","click"],"shrinkToFit":false,"ajaxDisableLink":false,"text":" \u003Cp\u003ETrend of snowpack instability and subsequent \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eavalanche\u003C\/a\u003E danger for this specific \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eavalanche\u003C\/a\u003E problem over the next 24 hours. There are three different possible trends: increasing danger, same danger, or decreasing danger.\u003C\/p\u003E\n ","list":["trigger","shrinkToFit"]},"beautytips_manager_custom_9":{"cssSelect":"span#problem-rose-info","style":"default","trigger":["click","click"],"shrinkToFit":false,"ajaxDisableLink":false,"text":" \u003Cp\u003EThe \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/aspect\u0022 title=\u0022The compass direction a slope faces (i.e. North, South, East, or West.)\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003EAspect\u003C\/a\u003E\/Elevation diagram describes the spatial pattern of the \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003EAvalanche\u003C\/a\u003E Problem by \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/aspect\u0022 title=\u0022The compass direction a slope faces (i.e. North, South, East, or West.)\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Easpect\u003C\/a\u003E (the direction a slope faces) and elevation band (Above, Near, or Below Treeline). The diagram will be filled with blue where the \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003EAvalanche\u003C\/a\u003E Problem exists. You can view the diagram as you would a mountain on a topographic map. The outer ring represents the Below Treeline elevation band, middle ring Near Treeline, and the inner ring Above Treeline. The diagram is oriented like a compass, with the top wedges representing north \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/aspect\u0022 title=\u0022The compass direction a slope faces (i.e. North, South, East, or West.)\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Easpects\u003C\/a\u003E, the left wedges representing west, etc.\u003C\/p\u003E\n ","list":["trigger","shrinkToFit"]},"beautytips_manager_custom_10":{"cssSelect":"span#avalanche-danger-scale-info","style":"default","trigger":["click","click"],"shrinkToFit":false,"ajaxDisableLink":false,"text":" \u003Cp\u003EThe North American \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003EAvalanche\u003C\/a\u003E Danger Scale is a five level scale used to communicate the danger of \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eavalanche\u003C\/a\u003E to backcountry recreationalists. \u003Cp\u003EAbove Treeline is the highest of the three elevation bands used in the SAC advisories. It includes alpine areas where the most snow falls and the winds are the strongest. It is not an exact elevation, but a characteristic of the terrain, beginning as the treeline transitions into open slopes extending to ridges and the tops of the highest peaks.\u003C\/p\u003E\n ","list":["trigger","shrinkToFit"]},"beautytips_manager_custom_4":{"cssSelect":"p#mid-rating-info","style":"default","trigger":["click","click"],"shrinkToFit":false,"ajaxDisableLink":false,"text":" \u003Cp\u003ENear Treeline is the middle of the three elevation bands used in the SAC advisories.   <div class="content">

 <tr>
   <th id="ob-header" colspan="2">
     <div><div class="field field-name-field-ob-loc-name field-type-text field-label-inline clearfix field-wrapper"><div  class="field-label">Location Name: </div><div  class="field-items"><div  class="field-item even">Upper Flume creek Sierra Buttes</div></div></div></div>
     <div><div class="field field-name-field-region field-type-list-text field-label-inline clearfix field-wrapper"><div  class="field-label">Region: </div><div  class="field-items"><div  class="field-item even">Outside of the Forecast Area</div></div></div></div>
     <div><div class="field field-name-field-ob-date-time field-type-datetime field-label-above field-wrapper"><div  class="field-label">Observation Date & Time or Estimated Date & Time of Avalanche: </div><div  class="field-items"><div  class="field-item even"><span class="date-display-single">Sunday, March 21, 2021 - 11:00</span></div></div></div></div>
     <div></div>
     <div></div>
   </th>
 </tr>
 <tr>
   <th id="ob-header">
     <div><div class="field field-name-field-location field-type-location field-label-above field-wrapper"><div  class="field-label">Location: </div><div  class="field-items"><div  class="field-item even"><div class="location vcard" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">
  <div class="adr">
                                                                <span class="geo"><abbr class="latitude" title="39.587521">39.587521</abbr>, <abbr
            class="longitude" title="-120.633384">-120.633384</abbr></span>
            </div>
      <div class="map-link">
      See map: <a href="https://caltopo.com/map.html#ll=39.587521,-120.633384&z=14&b=mbt" target="_blank">CalTopo</a>    </div>
  </div>
<div style="width: 100%; height: 400px;" id="gmap-auto2map-gmap0" class="gmap-control gmap-gmap gmap gmap-map gmap-auto2map-gmap"><noscript>Javascript is required to view this map.</noscript></div></div></div></div></div>
   </th>
   <td>
       <div class="field field-name-field-is-this-an-avalanche-obser field-type-list-boolean field-label-above field-wrapper"><div  class="field-label">Is this an Avalanche Observation?: </div><div  class="field-items"><div  class="field-item even">Yes</div></div></div>       <br>

 </tr>

<div id="position" class="Public">
	<strong>Observation made by: </strong>Public</div>
<div class='obs-pages'><div class="field-group-htabs-wrapper"><h2 class="element-invisible">Tabs</h2><div class="horizontal-tabs-panes"><fieldset class="collapsible collapsed group-quick-obs-dis field-group-htab form-wrapper"><legend><span class="fieldset-legend">Observation</span></legend><div class="fieldset-wrapper"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-above field-wrapper"><div  class="field-label">Description of Snow, Weather, and Avalanche Conditions: </div><div  class="field-items"><div  class="field-item even"><p>We remote triggered a 40 foot by 50 foot 8 inch deep wind slab about 40 feet below our skin track while going up. So we turned back to get to a spot to transition to ski down. I triggered a wind slab and sluff that knocked me over and drug me about  75 feet and buried me up to my waist. I was not hurt and self extracted. The crown at the top was about 4 inches tall but it was 1 to 2 feet deep by my tracks where I triggered it. The full path was about 50 feet wide and over 100 feet long </p>
</div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-ob-snowpit-photo field-type-image field-label-above field-wrapper"><div  class="field-label">Snowpit or crown profile photo or graph: </div><div  class="field-items"><div  class="field-item even"><a href="https://www.sierraavalanchecenter.org/sites/default/files/obs-img/65bb4342-f351-4a26-9000-483a31e59457.jpeg"><img src="https://www.sierraavalanchecenter.org/sites/default/files/styles/snowpits/public/obs-img/65bb4342-f351-4a26-9000-483a31e59457.jpeg?itok=_7KbBwOJ" width="800" height="1067" alt="" /></a></div><div  class="field-item even odd"><a href="https://www.sierraavalanchecenter.org/sites/default/files/obs-img/a081424b-bee0-4d13-a1f0-b1b3aa0b8d26.jpeg"><img src="https://www.sierraavalanchecenter.org/sites/default/files/styles/snowpits/public/obs-img/a081424b-bee0-4d13-a1f0-b1b3aa0b8d26.jpeg?itok=oscnaI1i" width="800" height="1067" alt="" /></a></div></div></div><fieldset class="collapsible form-wrapper"><legend><span class="fieldset-legend">Avalanche Details</span></legend><div class="fieldset-wrapper"><fieldset class="collapsible group-display-people-involved field-group-fieldset form-wrapper"><legend><span class="fieldset-legend">People Involved</span></legend><div class="fieldset-wrapper"><div class="field field-name-field-number-of-people-caught-2 field-type-list-integer field-label-above field-wrapper"><div  class="field-label">Number of people caught: </div><div  class="field-items"><div  class="field-item even">1</div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-number-of-partial-burials field-type-list-integer field-label-above field-wrapper inline"><div  class="field-label">Number of partial burials: </div><div  class="field-items"><div  class="field-item even">1</div></div></div></div></fieldset>

\u003Cp\u003EAbove Treeline is the highest of the three elevation bands used in the SAC advisories. It includes alpine areas where the most snow falls and the winds are the strongest. Wind slabs are often smooth and rounded and sometimes sound hollow.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003EWind slabs\u003C\/a\u003E that form over a \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/persistent-weak-layer\u0022 title=\u0022Weak layers that continue to produce avalanches for several days or weeks after a storm.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Epersistent weak layer\u003C\/a\u003E (\u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/surface-hoar\u0022 title=\u0022Featherly crystals that form on the snow surface during clear and calm conditions - essentially frozen dew.       <a id="main-content"></a>
                    <h1 class="title" id="page-title-observation" >
          Fatal Cornice Failure above Frog Lake Cliffs        </h1>
                          <div class="tabs">
                  </div>
                          <div class="region region-content">
    <div id="block-system-main" class="block block-system">

    
  <div class="content">
    <table class="obs-pages">
 <tr>
   <th id="ob-header" colspan="2">
     <div><div class="field field-name-field-ob-loc-name field-type-text field-label-inline clearfix field-wrapper"><div  class="field-label">Location Name: </div><div  class="field-items"><div  class="field-item even">Frog Lake Cliffs</div></div></div></div>
     <div><div class="field field-name-field-region field-type-list-text field-label-inline clearfix field-wrapper"><div  class="field-label">Region: </div><div  class="field-items"><div  class="field-item even">Donner Summit Area</div></div></div></div>
     <div><div class="field field-name-field-ob-date-time field-type-datetime field-label-above field-wrapper"><div  class="field-label">Observation Date & Time or Estimated Date & Time of Avalanche: </div><div  class="field-items"><div  class="field-item even"><span class="date-display-single">Saturday, March 20, 2021 - 12:50</span></div></div></div></div>
     <div></div>
     <div></div>
   </th>
 </tr>
 <tr>
   <th id="ob-header">
     <div><div class="field field-name-field-location field-type-location field-label-above field-wrapper"><div  class="field-label">Location: </div><div  class="field-items"><div  class="field-item even"><div class="location vcard" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">
  <div class="adr">
                                                                <span class="geo"><abbr class="latitude" title="39.368160">39.368160</abbr>, <abbr
            class="longitude" title="-120.329974">-120.329974</abbr></span>
            </div>
      <div class="map-link">
      See map: <a href="https://caltopo.com/map.html#ll=39.368160,-120.329974&z=14&b=mbt" target="_blank">CalTopo</a>    </div>
  </div>
<div style="width: 100%; height: 400px;" id="gmap-auto2map-gmap0" class="gmap-control gmap-gmap gmap gmap-map gmap-auto2map-gmap"><noscript>Javascript is required to view this map.</noscript></div></div></div></div></div>
   </th>
   <td>
       <div class="field field-name-field-is-this-an-avalanche-obser field-type-list-boolean field-label-above field-wrapper"><div  class="field-label">Is this an Avalanche Observation?: </div><div  class="field-items"><div  class="field-item even">Yes</div></div></div>       <br>
       <br>
       <div class="field field-name-field-conditions-alerts-tax-term field-type-taxonomy-term-reference field-label-above field-wrapper clearfix"><h3 class="field-label">Conditions Alerts: </h3><ul class="links"><li class="taxonomy-term-reference-0" class="field-item even"><span class="lineage-item lineage-item-level-0">Recent Loading</span></li></ul></div><br>
       <div class="field field-name-field-terrain-alerts field-type-list-text field-label-above field-wrapper"><div  class="field-label">Terrain Alerts: </div><div  class="field-items"><div  class="field-item even">Slopes Steeper than 30 degrees</div></div></div><br>
   </td>
 </tr>
</table>
<div id="position" class="Forecaster">
	<strong>Observation made by: </strong>Forecaster</div>
<div class='obs-pages'><div class="field-group-htabs-wrapper"><h2 class="element-invisible">Tabs</h2><div class="horizontal-tabs-panes"><fieldset class="collapsible collapsed group-quick-obs-dis field-group-htab form-wrapper"><legend><span class="fieldset-legend">Observation</span></legend><div class="fieldset-wrapper"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-above field-wrapper"><div  class="field-label">Description of Snow, Weather, and Avalanche Conditions: </div><div  class="field-items"><div  class="field-item even"><p>A fatal accident occurred near Frog Lake Cliffs today. Our thoughts, condolences, and sympathy are with all those affected by this tragedy. Our thanks also go out to those who helped with the recovery effort. This incident represents a sobering reminder of the risks that exist in the mountains. We visited this site on 3/21/21. Due to the steep technical nature of the terrain and the remaining large overhanging cornices we chose not to get close to the slope. Instead, we circumnavigated Frog Lake Cliffs and looked at the site from various angles from safe, accessible terrain. What we know is summarized below.</p>
<p>A group of three people snowmobiled to the top of Frog Lake Cliffs. The weather made visibility difficult and the light was very flat, making it hard to see the edge of the ridge. One of them stepped off their sled not realizing how close they were to the overhanging cornice on the edge of the ridge. They took a few steps towards the edge and a large (~40 ft) section of cornice broke underneath them. They fell onto the slope below with the large cornice pieces and triggered a wind slab avalanche on that slope. This avalanche was about 100 ft wide. The large cornice pieces and the avalanche swept the person down the slope over cliffs and through rocks and chutes. The avalanche debris was about 15 ft deep in places and about 100 ft wide. The avalanche size was about D2.5, R3.</p>
<p>The person came to rest about 900 vertical feet below the cornice. They were found on the surface (not buried) with traumatic injuries incompatible with life. Another party who witnessed the event from below initiated CPR before rescue crews arrived but the victim did not survive.</p>
<p>Rescue teams responded to the scene and used a helicopter to evacuate the body. The recovery effort was accomplished with cooperation from agencies including Nevada County SAR, Tahoe Nordic SAR, Placer County Avalanche Dog Team, NAS Fallon/US Navy, and Tahoe Donner XC.</p>
<p> </p>
</div></div></div><div class="slick slick--colorbox slick--skin--classic slick--optionset--slide-carousel-bar" id="slick-node-13195-observation-field-snowpack-avalanche-weather-1">

The footprints lead to the edge where the cornice broke." title="" class="media__image media__element lazy" src="data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIAAAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAAALAAAAAABAAEAAAIBRAA7" data-lazy="https://www.sierraavalanchecenter.org/sites/default/files/styles/large/public/obs-img/202103212017-img_20210321_103407919.jpg?itok=oM41Jt9T" /></div><span class="media-icon media-icon--lightbox media-icon--colorbox"></span></a><div class="litebox-caption element-invisible">The torn up snow is where the victim parked their snowmobile. The footprints lead to the edge where the cornice broke.</div>            
      
    </div>  </div>          <div class="slick__slide slide slide--1 slide--caption--below">      <div class="slide__content">            <a href="https://www.sierraavalanchecenter.org/sites/default/files/obs-img/202103212017-pxl_20210321_181942272_2.jpg" class="slick__colorbox litebox" data-media="{"type":"image","rel":"slick-node-13195-observation-field-snowpack-avalanche-weather-1"}"><div class="media media--image media--switch media--loading" data-thumb="https://www.sierraavalanchecenter.org/sites/default/files/styles/small_thumb/public/obs-img/202103212017-pxl_20210321_181942272_2.jpg?itok=5TwornNE"><img height="2268" width="4032" alt="Overview of the slope the victim fell down. <meta name="description" content="The group of skiers had descended a similar run, but slightly more E facing, a little more than an hour prior. <meta property="og:title" content="Avalanche above Meiss country" />
<meta property="og:description" content="The group of skiers had descended a similar run, but slightly more E facing, a little more than an hour prior. One skier descended to the top of where the slope steepened. The second skier skied towards the first, then asked for an audible for direction to the chute and continued towards it. Turns above the chute released sluff. The skier exited chute to skiers left. Skier then turned right. The turn triggered the slope and the skier lost footing and slid on their right side." />
<meta property="og:updated_time" content="2021-03-22T15:18:35-07:00" />

\u003Cp\u003EAbove Treeline is the highest of the three elevation bands used in the SAC advisories. It includes alpine areas where the most snow falls and the winds are the strongest. It is not an exact elevation, but a characteristic of the terrain, beginning as the treeline transitions into open slopes extending to ridges and the tops of the highest peaks.\u003C\/p\u003E\n ","list":["trigger","shrinkToFit"]},"beautytips_manager_custom_4":{"cssSelect":"p#mid-rating-info","style":"default","trigger":["click","click"],"shrinkToFit":false,"ajaxDisableLink":false,"text":" \u003Cp\u003ENear Treeline is the middle of the three elevation bands used in the SAC advisories. It is a transition zone between dense forests and treeless alpine areas. It is the narrowest of the three elevation bands, extending only a few hundred feet above and below the treeline. It varies locally, and is not a constant elevation or width.\u003C\/p\u003E\n ","list":["trigger","shrinkToFit"]},"beautytips_manager_custom_5":{"cssSelect":"p#lower-rating-info","style":"default","trigger":["click","click"],"shrinkToFit":false,"ajaxDisableLink":false,"text":" \u003Cp\u003EBelow Treeline is the lowest of three elevation bands used in the SAC advisories. It combines the spatial distribution of the problem and the sensitivity or ease of triggering an \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eavalanche\u003C\/a\u003E. The spatial distribution indicates how likely you are to encounter the problem in the highlighted \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eavalanche\u003C\/a\u003E terrain. The sensitive indicates how easy it is to \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/trigger\u0022 title=\u0022A disturbance that initiates fracture within the weak layer causing an avalanche. In 90 percent of avalanche accidents, the victim or someone in the victims party triggers the avalanche.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Etrigger\u003C\/a\u003E \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eavalanches\u003C\/a\u003E when you do encounter them. Sensitivity includes both natural or spontaneous release and human \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/trigger\u0022 title=\u0022A disturbance that initiates fracture within the weak layer causing an avalanche. In 90 percent of avalanche accidents, the victim or someone in the victims party triggers the avalanche.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Etriggered\u003C\/a\u003E \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eavalanches\u003C\/a\u003E.\u003C\/p\u003E\n ","list":["trigger","shrinkToFit"]},"beautytips_manager_custom_7":{"cssSelect":"span#size-info","style":"default","trigger":["click","click"],"shrinkToFit":false,"ajaxDisableLink":false,"text":" \u003Cp\u003ESize is based on the destructive potential of \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eavalanches\u003C\/a\u003E. SMALL (\u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/d1\u0022 title=\u0022Relatively harmless to people.\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003ED1\u003C\/a\u003E) \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eavalanches\u003C\/a\u003E are relatively harmless to people unless they push you into a \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/terrain-trap\u0022 title=\u0022Terrain in which the consequences of an avalanche are especially hazardous, such as a gully, an abrupt transition, an avalanche path that terminates in trees, a crevasse field or a cliff.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eterrain trap\u003C\/a\u003E. LARGE (\u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/d2\u0022 title=\u0022Could bury, injure, or kill a person.\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003ED2\u003C\/a\u003E) \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eavalanches\u003C\/a\u003E could bury, injure or kill a person. VERY LARGE (\u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/d3\u0022 title=\u0022Could bury and destroy a car, damage a truck, destroy a wood frame house, or break a few trees.\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003ED3\u003C\/a\u003E) \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eavalanches\u003C\/a\u003E could bury cars, destroy a house, or break trees. HISTORIC (\u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/d4\u0022 title=\u0022Could destroy a railway car, large truck, several buildings, or a substantial amount of forest.\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003ED4\u003C\/a\u003E \u0026amp;\u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/d5\u0022 title=\u0022Could gouge the landscape. Largest snow avalanche known.\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003ED5\u003C\/a\u003E) \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eavalanches\u003C\/a\u003E are even more destructive, nearing the maximum size the slope could produce and could destroy all or part of a small town.\u003C\/p\u003E\n ","list":["trigger","shrinkToFit"]},"beautytips_manager_custom_8":{"cssSelect":"span#trend-info","style":"default","trigger":["click","click"],"shrinkToFit":false,"ajaxDisableLink":false,"text":" \u003Cp\u003ETrend of snowpack instability and subsequent \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eavalanche\u003C\/a\u003E danger for this specific \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eavalanche\u003C\/a\u003E problem over the next 24 hours. There are three different possible trends: increasing danger, same danger, or decreasing danger.\u003C\/p\u003E\n ","list":["trigger","shrinkToFit"]},"beautytips_manager_custom_9":{"cssSelect":"span#problem-rose-info","style":"default","trigger":["click","click"],"shrinkToFit":false,"ajaxDisableLink":false,"text":" \u003Cp\u003EThe \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/aspect\u0022 title=\u0022The compass direction a slope faces (i.e. North, South, East, or West.)\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003EAspect\u003C\/a\u003E\/Elevation diagram describes the spatial pattern of the \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003EAvalanche\u003C\/a\u003E Problem by \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/aspect\u0022 title=\u0022The compass direction a slope faces (i.e. North, South, East, or West.)\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Easpect\u003C\/a\u003E (the direction a slope faces) and elevation band (Above, Near, or Below Treeline). The diagram will be filled with blue where the \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003EAvalanche\u003C\/a\u003E Problem exists. You can view the diagram as you would a mountain on a topographic map. The outer ring represents the Below Treeline elevation band, middle ring Near Treeline, and the inner ring Above Treeline.        <br>
       <div class="field field-name-field-conditions-alerts-tax-term field-type-taxonomy-term-reference field-label-above field-wrapper clearfix"><h3 class="field-label">Conditions Alerts: </h3><ul class="links"><li class="taxonomy-term-reference-0" class="field-item even"><span class="lineage-item lineage-item-level-0">Rapid or Prolonged Warming</span><span class="hierarchical-select-item-separator">›</span><span class="lineage-item lineage-item-level-1">Strong Sunshine</span></li><li class="taxonomy-term-reference-1" class="field-item even odd"><span class="lineage-item lineage-item-level-0">Rapid or Prolonged Warming</span><span class="hierarchical-select-item-separator">›</span><span class="lineage-item lineage-item-level-1">Warm Temperatures</span></li><li class="taxonomy-term-reference-2" class="field-item even odd even"><span class="lineage-item lineage-item-level-0">Recent Loading</span></li></ul></div><br>
       <div class="field field-name-field-terrain-alerts field-type-list-text field-label-above field-wrapper"><div  class="field-label">Terrain Alerts: </div><div  class="field-items"><div  class="field-item even">Slopes Steeper than 30 degrees</div><div  class="field-item even odd">Trigger Points</div><div  class="field-item even odd even">Terrain Traps</div></div></div><br>

<div id="position" class="Public">
	<strong>Observation made by: </strong>Public</div>
<div class='obs-pages'><div class="field-group-htabs-wrapper"><h2 class="element-invisible">Tabs</h2><div class="horizontal-tabs-panes"><fieldset class="collapsible collapsed group-quick-obs-dis field-group-htab form-wrapper"><legend><span class="fieldset-legend">Observation</span></legend><div class="fieldset-wrapper"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-above field-wrapper"><div  class="field-label">Description of Snow, Weather, and Avalanche Conditions: </div><div  class="field-items"><div  class="field-item even"><p>The group of skiers had descended a similar run, but slightly more E facing, a little more than an hour prior. One skier descended to the top of where the slope steepened. The second skier skied towards the first, then asked for an audible for direction to the chute and continued towards it. Turns above the chute released sluff. The skier exited chute to skiers left. Skier then turned right. The turn triggered the slope and the skier lost footing and slid on their right side. Skier was able to self arrest with aid of their arm and their ski just above (or within) the lowest cliff band. One ski remained on the foot and jammed between the rocks, preventing further engagement of the rock and cliff-fall. The slide cleared over the clif, triggering a crown at the clif base. The skier, unharmed, was able to self-extract, sidehill, exit, put on the second ski found on the surface below the rocks and ski out of the slide path before their party descended. It is unclear if the whole crown was triggered by the right turn, or if the sluff from above the skier entrance into the chute caused the skiers right side of the crown to release independenlty. The slide path piled snow on the uphill side of the trees 2m thick at the top of the runout.</p>
<p> </p>
<p>Pic 1: overview</p>
<p>Pic 2: below bottom cliff, picture taken from big trees in pic3. Lookers left crown may have been triggered separately. </p>
<p>Pic 3: debris path</p>
<p> </p>
</div></div></div><div class="slick slick--colorbox slick--skin--classic slick--optionset--slide-carousel-bar" id="slick-node-13208-observation-field-snowpack-avalanche-weather-1">

I went down hill head first and came to a rest on top of the small debris pile. Uninjured but lost a ski pole. I thought I was in a safe spot to test the cornice but it broke further away from the edge than I anticipated. I spend a lot of time in this zone and today I got complacent. I let my guard down and almost paid the price. " />

\u003Cp\u003EAbove Treeline is the highest of the three elevation bands used in the SAC advisories. It includes alpine areas where the most snow falls and the winds are the strongest. It is not an exact elevation, but a characteristic of the terrain, beginning as the treeline transitions into open slopes extending to ridges and the tops of the highest peaks.\u003C\/p\u003E\n ","list":["trigger","shrinkToFit"]},"beautytips_manager_custom_4":{"cssSelect":"p#mid-rating-info","style":"default","trigger":["click","click"],"shrinkToFit":false,"ajaxDisableLink":false,"text":" \u003Cp\u003ENear Treeline is the middle of the three elevation bands used in the SAC advisories. It is a transition zone between dense forests and treeless alpine areas. It is the narrowest of the three elevation bands, extending only a few hundred feet above and below the treeline. It varies locally, and is not a constant elevation or width.\u003C\/p\u003E\n ","list":["trigger","shrinkToFit"]},"beautytips_manager_custom_5":{"cssSelect":"p#lower-rating-info","style":"default","trigger":["click","click"],"shrinkToFit":false,"ajaxDisableLink":false,"text":" \u003Cp\u003EBelow Treeline is the lowest of three elevation bands used in the SAC advisories. Tree cover shelters the snow from wind effects.\u003C\/p\u003E\n ","list":["trigger","shrinkToFit"]},"beautytips_manager_custom_6":{"cssSelect":"span#likelihood-info","style":"default","trigger":["click","click"],"shrinkToFit":false,"ajaxDisableLink":false,"text":" \u003Cp\u003ELikelihood is a description of the chance of encountering a particular \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eavalanche\u003C\/a\u003E problem. Often the layer in the snowpack where an avalanche fractures.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eweak layers\u003C\/a\u003E involved in deep, persistent \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/slab\u0022 title=\u0022A relatively cohesive snowpack layer.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eslabs\u003C\/a\u003E are \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/depth-hoar\u0022 title=\u0022Large-grained, faceted, cup-shaped crystals near the ground. <div id="position" class="Public">
	<strong>Observation made by: </strong>Public</div>
<div class='obs-pages'><div class="field-group-htabs-wrapper"><h2 class="element-invisible">Tabs</h2><div class="horizontal-tabs-panes"><fieldset class="collapsible collapsed group-quick-obs-dis field-group-htab form-wrapper"><legend><span class="fieldset-legend">Observation</span></legend><div class="fieldset-wrapper"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-above field-wrapper"><div  class="field-label">Description of Snow, Weather, and Avalanche Conditions: </div><div  class="field-items"><div  class="field-item even"><p>I was served a thick slice of humble pie today. </p>
<p>I intentionally kicked at a cornice that broke off underneath my skis and took me for a short ride. I went down hill head first and came to a rest on top of the small debris pile. Uninjured but lost a ski pole.</p>
<p>I thought I was in a safe spot to test the cornice but it broke further away from the edge than I anticipated. I spend a lot of time in this zone and today I got complacent. I let my guard down and almost paid the price. </p>
<p>I'm extremely embarrssed but I wanted to share as a reminder to others. Don't get complacent. Don't let seemingly tame conditions deceive you. </p>
</div></div></div><div class="slick slick--colorbox slick--less slick--skin--classic slick--optionset--slide-carousel-bar unslick" id="slick-node-13184-observation-field-snowpack-avalanche-weather-1">

It is not an exact elevation, but a characteristic of the terrain, beginning as the treeline transitions into open slopes extending to ridges and the tops of the highest peaks.\u003C\/p\u003E\n ","list":["trigger","shrinkToFit"]},"beautytips_manager_custom_4":{"cssSelect":"p#mid-rating-info","style":"default","trigger":["click","click"],"shrinkToFit":false,"ajaxDisableLink":false,"text":" \u003Cp\u003ENear Treeline is the middle of the three elevation bands used in the SAC advisories. <meta property="og:title" content="Avalanche at taking mountain" />
<meta property="og:description" content="We dropped in west of talking mountain, between talking and cup lake. I was on a splitboard and my partner dan was on skis. We traversed east into rolling powder 30-35 degrees, I came to a steeper section of about 40 degrees. Made a few turns and was followed by what looked like surface sluff, then momements later saw both sides of me moving faster than I was. I announced "avalanche" into the radio, triggered my airbag, was knocked down and slid along on my back about 20 feet toward a small group of trees and pushed my board away from each tree." />

\u003Cp\u003EAbove Treeline is the highest of the three elevation bands used in the SAC advisories. It includes alpine areas where the most snow falls and the winds are the strongest. It is not an exact elevation, but a characteristic of the terrain, beginning as the treeline transitions into open slopes extending to ridges and the tops of the highest peaks.\u003C\/p\u003E\n ","list":["trigger","shrinkToFit"]},"beautytips_manager_custom_4":{"cssSelect":"p#mid-rating-info","style":"default","trigger":["click","click"],"shrinkToFit":false,"ajaxDisableLink":false,"text":" \u003Cp\u003ENear Treeline is the middle of the three elevation bands used in the SAC advisories. It is a transition zone between dense forests and treeless alpine areas. It is the narrowest of the three elevation bands, extending only a few hundred feet above and below the treeline. It varies locally, and is not a constant elevation or width.\u003C\/p\u003E\n ","list":["trigger","shrinkToFit"]},"beautytips_manager_custom_5":{"cssSelect":"p#lower-rating-info","style":"default","trigger":["click","click"],"shrinkToFit":false,"ajaxDisableLink":false,"text":" \u003Cp\u003EBelow Treeline is the lowest of three elevation bands used in the SAC advisories.       <a id="main-content"></a>
                    <h1 class="title" id="page-title-observation" >
          Avalanche at taking mountain        </h1>
                          <div class="tabs">
                  </div>
                          <div class="region region-content">
    <div id="block-system-main" class="block block-system">

    
  <div class="content">
    <table class="obs-pages">
 <tr>
   <th id="ob-header" colspan="2">
     <div><div class="field field-name-field-ob-loc-name field-type-text field-label-inline clearfix field-wrapper"><div  class="field-label">Location Name: </div><div  class="field-items"><div  class="field-item even">Talking mountain</div></div></div></div>
     <div><div class="field field-name-field-region field-type-list-text field-label-inline clearfix field-wrapper"><div  class="field-label">Region: </div><div  class="field-items"><div  class="field-item even">Echo Summit Area</div></div></div></div>
     <div><div class="field field-name-field-ob-date-time field-type-datetime field-label-above field-wrapper"><div  class="field-label">Observation Date & Time or Estimated Date & Time of Avalanche: </div><div  class="field-items"><div  class="field-item even"><span class="date-display-single">Sunday, February 14, 2021 - 12:30</span></div></div></div></div>
     <div></div>
     <div></div>
   </th>
 </tr>
 <tr>
   <th id="ob-header">
     <div><div class="field field-name-field-location field-type-location field-label-above field-wrapper"><div  class="field-label">Location: </div><div  class="field-items"><div  class="field-item even"><div class="location vcard" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/PostalAddress">
  <div class="adr">
                                                                <span class="geo"><abbr class="latitude" title="38.835708">38.835708</abbr>, <abbr
            class="longitude" title="-120.071854">-120.071854</abbr></span>
            </div>
      <div class="map-link">
      See map: <a href="https://caltopo.com/map.html#ll=38.835708,-120.071854&z=14&b=mbt" target="_blank">CalTopo</a>    </div>
  </div>
<div style="width: 100%; height: 400px;" id="gmap-auto2map-gmap0" class="gmap-control gmap-gmap gmap gmap-map gmap-auto2map-gmap"><noscript>Javascript is required to view this map.</noscript></div></div></div></div></div>
   </th>
   <td>
       <div class="field field-name-field-is-this-an-avalanche-obser field-type-list-boolean field-label-above field-wrapper"><div  class="field-label">Is this an Avalanche Observation?: </div><div  class="field-items"><div  class="field-item even">Yes</div></div></div>       <br>
       <br>
       <div class="field field-name-field-conditions-alerts-tax-term field-type-taxonomy-term-reference field-label-above field-wrapper clearfix"><h3 class="field-label">Conditions Alerts: </h3><ul class="links"><li class="taxonomy-term-reference-0" class="field-item even"><span class="lineage-item lineage-item-level-0">Avalanche Activity</span></li></ul></div><br>
       <div class="field field-name-field-terrain-alerts field-type-list-text field-label-above field-wrapper"><div  class="field-label">Terrain Alerts: </div><div  class="field-items"><div  class="field-item even">Slopes Steeper than 30 degrees</div><div  class="field-item even odd">Trigger Points</div></div></div><br>
   </td>
 </tr>
</table>
<div id="position" class="Public">
	<strong>Observation made by: </strong>Public</div>
<div class='obs-pages'><div class="field-group-htabs-wrapper"><h2 class="element-invisible">Tabs</h2><div class="horizontal-tabs-panes"><fieldset class="collapsible collapsed group-quick-obs-dis field-group-htab form-wrapper"><legend><span class="fieldset-legend">Observation</span></legend><div class="fieldset-wrapper"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-above field-wrapper"><div  class="field-label">Description of Snow, Weather, and Avalanche Conditions: </div><div  class="field-items"><div  class="field-item even"><p>We dropped in west of talking mountain, between talking and cup lake. I was on a splitboard and my partner dan was on skis. We traversed east into rolling powder 30-35 degrees, I came to a steeper section of about 40 degrees. Made a few turns and was followed by what looked like surface sluff, then momements later saw both sides of me moving faster than I was. I announced "avalanche" into the radio, triggered my airbag, was knocked down and slid along on my back about 20 feet toward a small group of trees and pushed my board away from each tree. I came to a stop shortly after in a safer area on the edge of the track. The runout was for another 50' and about 60' wide. Dan observed signs of two other recent avalanches in the area.</p>
</div></div></div><div class="slick slick--colorbox slick--skin--classic slick--optionset--slide-carousel-bar" id="slick-node-12959-observation-field-snowpack-avalanche-weather-1">

<meta property="og:description" content="Recent Avalanche: A small avalanche caused by either a skier or snowboarder (one track into slide path over the crown, guessing skier based on the tracks observed above). Crown height was about 3 inches The path immediately funneled into a terrain trap and a tree directly at the bottom of the chute had snow piled onto it more than 6 ft high. Dug a quick hand pit and saw another suspect layer about 2" deeper than the bed surface. Saw another recent avalanche in a similar elevation, aspect, area, size. but didn't get close enough to take photos." />

\u003Cp\u003EAbove Treeline is the highest of the three elevation bands used in the SAC advisories. It includes alpine areas where the most snow falls and the winds are the strongest. It is not an exact elevation, but a characteristic of the terrain, beginning as the treeline transitions into open slopes extending to ridges and the tops of the highest peaks.\u003C\/p\u003E\n ","list":["trigger","shrinkToFit"]},"beautytips_manager_custom_4":{"cssSelect":"p#mid-rating-info","style":"default","trigger":["click","click"],"shrinkToFit":false,"ajaxDisableLink":false,"text":" \u003Cp\u003ENear Treeline is the middle of the three elevation bands used in the SAC advisories. It is a transition zone between dense forests and treeless alpine areas. It is the narrowest of the three elevation bands, extending only a few hundred feet above and below the treeline. It varies locally, and is not a constant elevation or width.\u003C\/p\u003E\n ","list":["trigger","shrinkToFit"]},"beautytips_manager_custom_5":{"cssSelect":"p#lower-rating-info","style":"default","trigger":["click","click"],"shrinkToFit":false,"ajaxDisableLink":false,"text":" \u003Cp\u003EBelow Treeline is the lowest of three elevation bands used in the SAC advisories. Tree cover shelters the snow from wind effects.\u003C\/p\u003E\n ","list":["trigger","shrinkToFit"]},"beautytips_manager_custom_6":{"cssSelect":"span#likelihood-info","style":"default","trigger":["click","click"],"shrinkToFit":false,"ajaxDisableLink":false,"text":" \u003Cp\u003ELikelihood is a description of the chance of encountering a particular \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eavalanche\u003C\/a\u003E problem. It combines the spatial distribution of the problem and the sensitivity or ease of triggering an \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eavalanche\u003C\/a\u003E. The spatial distribution indicates how likely you are to encounter the problem in the highlighted \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eavalanche\u003C\/a\u003E terrain. The sensitive indicates how easy it is to \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/trigger\u0022 title=\u0022A disturbance that initiates fracture within the weak layer causing an avalanche. In 90 percent of avalanche accidents, the victim or someone in the victims party triggers the avalanche.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Etrigger\u003C\/a\u003E \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eavalanches\u003C\/a\u003E when you do encounter them. Sensitivity includes both natural or spontaneous release and human \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/trigger\u0022 title=\u0022A disturbance that initiates fracture within the weak layer causing an avalanche. In 90 percent of avalanche accidents, the victim or someone in the victims party triggers the avalanche.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Etriggered\u003C\/a\u003E \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eavalanches\u003C\/a\u003E.\u003C\/p\u003E\n ","list":["trigger","shrinkToFit"]},"beautytips_manager_custom_7":{"cssSelect":"span#size-info","style":"default","trigger":["click","click"],"shrinkToFit":false,"ajaxDisableLink":false,"text":" \u003Cp\u003ESize is based on the destructive potential of \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eavalanches\u003C\/a\u003E. SMALL (\u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/d1\u0022 title=\u0022Relatively harmless to people.\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003ED1\u003C\/a\u003E) \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eavalanches\u003C\/a\u003E are relatively harmless to people unless they push you into a \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/terrain-trap\u0022 title=\u0022Terrain in which the consequences of an avalanche are especially hazardous, such as a gully, an abrupt transition, an avalanche path that terminates in trees, a crevasse field or a cliff.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eterrain trap\u003C\/a\u003E. LARGE (\u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/d2\u0022 title=\u0022Could bury, injure, or kill a person.\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003ED2\u003C\/a\u003E) \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eavalanches\u003C\/a\u003E could bury, injure or kill a person. VERY LARGE (\u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/d3\u0022 title=\u0022Could bury and destroy a car, damage a truck, destroy a wood frame house, or break a few trees.\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003ED3\u003C\/a\u003E) \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eavalanches\u003C\/a\u003E could bury cars, destroy a house, or break trees. HISTORIC (\u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/d4\u0022 title=\u0022Could destroy a railway car, large truck, several buildings, or a substantial amount of forest.\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003ED4\u003C\/a\u003E \u0026amp;\u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/d5\u0022 title=\u0022Could gouge the landscape. Largest snow avalanche known.\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003ED5\u003C\/a\u003E) \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eavalanches\u003C\/a\u003E are even more destructive, nearing the maximum size the slope could produce and could destroy all or part of a small town.\u003C\/p\u003E\n ","list":["trigger","shrinkToFit"]},"beautytips_manager_custom_8":{"cssSelect":"span#trend-info","style":"default","trigger":["click","click"],"shrinkToFit":false,"ajaxDisableLink":false,"text":" \u003Cp\u003ETrend of snowpack instability and subsequent \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eavalanche\u003C\/a\u003E danger for this specific \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eavalanche\u003C\/a\u003E problem over the next 24 hours. There are three different possible trends: increasing danger, same danger, or decreasing danger.\u003C\/p\u003E\n ","list":["trigger","shrinkToFit"]},"beautytips_manager_custom_9":{"cssSelect":"span#problem-rose-info","style":"default","trigger":["click","click"],"shrinkToFit":false,"ajaxDisableLink":false,"text":" \u003Cp\u003EThe \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/aspect\u0022 title=\u0022The compass direction a slope faces (i.e. North, South, East, or West.)\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003EAspect\u003C\/a\u003E\/Elevation diagram describes the spatial pattern of the \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003EAvalanche\u003C\/a\u003E Problem by \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/aspect\u0022 title=\u0022The compass direction a slope faces (i.e. North, South, East, or West.)\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Easpect\u003C\/a\u003E (the direction a slope faces) and elevation band (Above, Near, or Below Treeline). The diagram will be filled with blue where the \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003EAvalanche\u003C\/a\u003E Problem exists. You can view the diagram as you would a mountain on a topographic map. The outer ring represents the Below Treeline elevation band, middle ring Near Treeline, and the inner ring Above Treeline. The diagram is oriented like a compass, with the top wedges representing north \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/aspect\u0022 title=\u0022The compass direction a slope faces (i.e. North, South, East, or West.)\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Easpects\u003C\/a\u003E, the left wedges representing west, etc.\u003C\/p\u003E\n ","list":["trigger","shrinkToFit"]},"beautytips_manager_custom_10":{"cssSelect":"span#avalanche-danger-scale-info","style":"default","trigger":["click","click"],"shrinkToFit":false,"ajaxDisableLink":false,"text":" \u003Cp\u003EThe North American \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003EAvalanche\u003C\/a\u003E Danger Scale is a five level scale used to communicate the danger of \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eavalanche\u003C\/a\u003E to backcountry recreationalists. The danger is a combination of the expected likelihood, size, and distribution of \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eavalanches\u003C\/a\u003E. It provides a very basic description of the \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eavalanche\u003C\/a\u003E conditions. You can find more details in the other parts of the SAC \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003EAvalanche\u003C\/a\u003E Advisory.\u003C\/p\u003E\n ","list":["trigger","shrinkToFit"]},"beautytips_manager_custom_11":{"cssSelect":"span#avalanche-problems-info","style":"default","trigger":["click","click"],"shrinkToFit":false,"ajaxDisableLink":false,"text":" \u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003EAvalanche\u003C\/a\u003E Problems are categories of \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eavalanche\u003C\/a\u003E activity. <div id="position" class="Public">
	<strong>Observation made by: </strong>Public</div>
<div class='obs-pages'><div class="field-group-htabs-wrapper"><h2 class="element-invisible">Tabs</h2><div class="horizontal-tabs-panes"><fieldset class="collapsible collapsed group-quick-obs-dis field-group-htab form-wrapper"><legend><span class="fieldset-legend">Observation</span></legend><div class="fieldset-wrapper"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-above field-wrapper"><div  class="field-label">Description of Snow, Weather, and Avalanche Conditions: </div><div  class="field-items"><div  class="field-item even"><p>Recent Avalanche: A small avalanche caused by either a skier or snowboarder (one track into slide path over the crown, guessing skier based on the tracks observed above). Crown height was about 3 inches The path immediately funneled into a terrain trap and a tree directly at the bottom of the chute had snow piled onto it more than 6 ft high. Dug a quick hand pit and saw another suspect layer about 2" deeper than the bed surface.</p>
<p>	Saw another recent avalanche in a similar elevation, aspect, area, size. but didn't get close enough to take photos.</p>
</div></div></div><div class="slick slick--colorbox slick--less slick--skin--classic slick--optionset--slide-carousel-bar" id="slick-node-12968-observation-field-snowpack-avalanche-weather-1">

\u003Cp\u003EAbove Treeline is the highest of the three elevation bands used in the SAC advisories. It includes alpine areas where the most snow falls and the winds are the strongest. It is not an exact elevation, but a characteristic of the terrain, beginning as the treeline transitions into open slopes extending to ridges and the tops of the highest peaks.\u003C\/p\u003E\n ","list":["trigger","shrinkToFit"]},"beautytips_manager_custom_4":{"cssSelect":"p#mid-rating-info","style":"default","trigger":["click","click"],"shrinkToFit":false,"ajaxDisableLink":false,"text":" \u003Cp\u003ENear Treeline is the middle of the three elevation bands used in the SAC advisories. It is a transition zone between dense forests and treeless alpine areas. It is the narrowest of the three elevation bands, extending only a few hundred feet above and below the treeline. It varies locally, and is not a constant elevation or width.\u003C\/p\u003E\n ","list":["trigger","shrinkToFit"]},"beautytips_manager_custom_5":{"cssSelect":"p#lower-rating-info","style":"default","trigger":["click","click"],"shrinkToFit":false,"ajaxDisableLink":false,"text":" \u003Cp\u003EBelow Treeline is the lowest of three elevation bands used in the SAC advisories. It extends from valley floors or snowline to Near Treeline. Open areas and sparse trees are possible. Snowfall tends to be less than the other elevation bands. Tree cover shelters the snow from wind effects.\u003C\/p\u003E\n ","list":["trigger","shrinkToFit"]},"beautytips_manager_custom_6":{"cssSelect":"span#likelihood-info","style":"default","trigger":["click","click"],"shrinkToFit":false,"ajaxDisableLink":false,"text":" \u003Cp\u003ELikelihood is a description of the chance of encountering a particular \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eavalanche\u003C\/a\u003E problem. It combines the spatial distribution of the problem and the sensitivity or ease of triggering an \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eavalanche\u003C\/a\u003E. The spatial distribution indicates how likely you are to encounter the problem in the highlighted \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eavalanche\u003C\/a\u003E terrain. The sensitive indicates how easy it is to \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/trigger\u0022 title=\u0022A disturbance that initiates fracture within the weak layer causing an avalanche. In 90 percent of avalanche accidents, the victim or someone in the victims party triggers the avalanche.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Etrigger\u003C\/a\u003E \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eavalanches\u003C\/a\u003E when you do encounter them. Sensitivity includes both natural or spontaneous release and human \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/trigger\u0022 title=\u0022A disturbance that initiates fracture within the weak layer causing an avalanche. In 90 percent of avalanche accidents, the victim or someone in the victims party triggers the avalanche.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Etriggered\u003C\/a\u003E \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eavalanches\u003C\/a\u003E.\u003C\/p\u003E\n ","list":["trigger","shrinkToFit"]},"beautytips_manager_custom_7":{"cssSelect":"span#size-info","style":"default","trigger":["click","click"],"shrinkToFit":false,"ajaxDisableLink":false,"text":" \u003Cp\u003ESize is based on the destructive potential of \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eavalanches\u003C\/a\u003E. SMALL (\u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/d1\u0022 title=\u0022Relatively harmless to people.\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003ED1\u003C\/a\u003E) \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eavalanches\u003C\/a\u003E are relatively harmless to people unless they push you into a \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/terrain-trap\u0022 title=\u0022Terrain in which the consequences of an avalanche are especially hazardous, such as a gully, an abrupt transition, an avalanche path that terminates in trees, a crevasse field or a cliff.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eterrain trap\u003C\/a\u003E. LARGE (\u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/d2\u0022 title=\u0022Could bury, injure, or kill a person.\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003ED2\u003C\/a\u003E) \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eavalanches\u003C\/a\u003E could bury, injure or kill a person. VERY LARGE (\u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/d3\u0022 title=\u0022Could bury and destroy a car, damage a truck, destroy a wood frame house, or break a few trees.\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003ED3\u003C\/a\u003E) \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eavalanches\u003C\/a\u003E could bury cars, destroy a house, or break trees. HISTORIC (\u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/d4\u0022 title=\u0022Could destroy a railway car, large truck, several buildings, or a substantial amount of forest.\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003ED4\u003C\/a\u003E \u0026amp;\u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/d5\u0022 title=\u0022Could gouge the landscape. Largest snow avalanche known.\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003ED5\u003C\/a\u003E) \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eavalanches\u003C\/a\u003E are even more destructive, nearing the maximum size the slope could produce and could destroy all or part of a small town.\u003C\/p\u003E\n ","list":["trigger","shrinkToFit"]},"beautytips_manager_custom_8":{"cssSelect":"span#trend-info","style":"default","trigger":["click","click"],"shrinkToFit":false,"ajaxDisableLink":false,"text":" \u003Cp\u003ETrend of snowpack instability and subsequent \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eavalanche\u003C\/a\u003E danger for this specific \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eavalanche\u003C\/a\u003E problem over the next 24 hours. There are three different possible trends: increasing danger, same danger, or decreasing danger.\u003C\/p\u003E\n ","list":["trigger","shrinkToFit"]},"beautytips_manager_custom_9":{"cssSelect":"span#problem-rose-info","style":"default","trigger":["click","click"],"shrinkToFit":false,"ajaxDisableLink":false,"text":" \u003Cp\u003EThe \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/aspect\u0022 title=\u0022The compass direction a slope faces (i.e. North, South, East, or West.)\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003EAspect\u003C\/a\u003E\/Elevation diagram describes the spatial pattern of the \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003EAvalanche\u003C\/a\u003E Problem by \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/aspect\u0022 title=\u0022The compass direction a slope faces (i.e. North, South, East, or West.)\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Easpect\u003C\/a\u003E (the direction a slope faces) and elevation band (Above, Near, or Below Treeline). The diagram will be filled with blue where the \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003EAvalanche\u003C\/a\u003E Problem exists. You can view the diagram as you would a mountain on a topographic map. The outer ring represents the Below Treeline elevation band, middle ring Near Treeline, and the inner ring Above Treeline. The diagram is oriented like a compass, with the top wedges representing north \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/aspect\u0022 title=\u0022The compass direction a slope faces (i.e. North, South, East, or West.)\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Easpects\u003C\/a\u003E, the left wedges representing west, etc.\u003C\/p\u003E\n ","list":["trigger","shrinkToFit"]},"beautytips_manager_custom_10":{"cssSelect":"span#avalanche-danger-scale-info","style":"default","trigger":["click","click"],"shrinkToFit":false,"ajaxDisableLink":false,"text":" \u003Cp\u003EThe North American \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003EAvalanche\u003C\/a\u003E Danger Scale is a five level scale used to communicate the danger of \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eavalanche\u003C\/a\u003E to backcountry recreationalists. <div class='obs-pages'><div class="field-group-htabs-wrapper"><h2 class="element-invisible">Tabs</h2><div class="horizontal-tabs-panes"><fieldset class="collapsible collapsed group-quick-obs-dis field-group-htab form-wrapper"><legend><span class="fieldset-legend">Observation</span></legend><div class="fieldset-wrapper"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-above field-wrapper"><div  class="field-label">Description of Snow, Weather, and Avalanche Conditions: </div><div  class="field-items"><div  class="field-item even"><p>Snowboarder triggered the avalanche. Area of the trigger had rock surfaces below and there was a slight convex rollover.</p>
<p>We performed an ECT test adjacent to the to avalanche site and found relatively stable snow with no propagation, suggesting the avalanche was most likely triggered by poor adhesion of storm slab to the rock surface.</p>
<p> </p>

\u003Cp\u003EAbove Treeline is the highest of the three elevation bands used in the SAC advisories. It includes alpine areas where the most snow falls and the winds are the strongest. It is not an exact elevation, but a characteristic of the terrain, beginning as the treeline transitions into open slopes extending to ridges and the tops of the highest peaks.\u003C\/p\u003E\n ","list":["trigger","shrinkToFit"]},"beautytips_manager_custom_4":{"cssSelect":"p#mid-rating-info","style":"default","trigger":["click","click"],"shrinkToFit":false,"ajaxDisableLink":false,"text":" \u003Cp\u003ENear Treeline is the middle of the three elevation bands used in the SAC advisories. It is a transition zone between dense forests and treeless alpine areas. It is the narrowest of the three elevation bands, extending only a few hundred feet above and below the treeline. It varies locally, and is not a constant elevation or width.\u003C\/p\u003E\n ","list":["trigger","shrinkToFit"]},"beautytips_manager_custom_5":{"cssSelect":"p#lower-rating-info","style":"default","trigger":["click","click"],"shrinkToFit":false,"ajaxDisableLink":false,"text":" \u003Cp\u003EBelow Treeline is the lowest of three elevation bands used in the SAC advisories. It extends from valley floors or snowline to Near Treeline. Open areas and sparse trees are possible. Snowfall tends to be less than the other elevation bands. Tree cover shelters the snow from wind effects.\u003C\/p\u003E\n ","list":["trigger","shrinkToFit"]},"beautytips_manager_custom_6":{"cssSelect":"span#likelihood-info","style":"default","trigger":["click","click"],"shrinkToFit":false,"ajaxDisableLink":false,"text":" \u003Cp\u003ELikelihood is a description of the chance of encountering a particular \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eavalanche\u003C\/a\u003E problem. It combines the spatial distribution of the problem and the sensitivity or ease of triggering an \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eavalanche\u003C\/a\u003E. The spatial distribution indicates how likely you are to encounter the problem in the highlighted \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eavalanche\u003C\/a\u003E terrain. The sensitive indicates how easy it is to \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/trigger\u0022 title=\u0022A disturbance that initiates fracture within the weak layer causing an avalanche. In 90 percent of avalanche accidents, the victim or someone in the victims party triggers the avalanche.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Etrigger\u003C\/a\u003E \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eavalanches\u003C\/a\u003E when you do encounter them. Sensitivity includes both natural or spontaneous release and human \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/trigger\u0022 title=\u0022A disturbance that initiates fracture within the weak layer causing an avalanche. In 90 percent of avalanche accidents, the victim or someone in the victims party triggers the avalanche.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Etriggered\u003C\/a\u003E \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eavalanches\u003C\/a\u003E.\u003C\/p\u003E\n ","list":["trigger","shrinkToFit"]},"beautytips_manager_custom_7":{"cssSelect":"span#size-info","style":"default","trigger":["click","click"],"shrinkToFit":false,"ajaxDisableLink":false,"text":" \u003Cp\u003ESize is based on the destructive potential of \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eavalanches\u003C\/a\u003E. SMALL (\u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/d1\u0022 title=\u0022Relatively harmless to people.\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003ED1\u003C\/a\u003E) \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eavalanches\u003C\/a\u003E are relatively harmless to people unless they push you into a \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/terrain-trap\u0022 title=\u0022Terrain in which the consequences of an avalanche are especially hazardous, such as a gully, an abrupt transition, an avalanche path that terminates in trees, a crevasse field or a cliff.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eterrain trap\u003C\/a\u003E. LARGE (\u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/d2\u0022 title=\u0022Could bury, injure, or kill a person.\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003ED2\u003C\/a\u003E) \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eavalanches\u003C\/a\u003E could bury, injure or kill a person. VERY LARGE (\u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/d3\u0022 title=\u0022Could bury and destroy a car, damage a truck, destroy a wood frame house, or break a few trees.\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003ED3\u003C\/a\u003E) \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eavalanches\u003C\/a\u003E could bury cars, destroy a house, or break trees. \u003Cp\u003EAbove Treeline is the highest of the three elevation bands used in the SAC advisories. It includes alpine areas where the most snow falls and the winds are the strongest.
