SMALL (\u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/d1\u0022 title=\u0022Relatively harmless to people.\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003ED1\u003C\/a\u003E) \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eavalanches\u003C\/a\u003E are relatively harmless to people unless they push you into a \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/terrain-trap\u0022 title=\u0022Terrain in which the consequences of an avalanche are especially hazardous, such as a gully, an abrupt transition, an avalanche path that terminates in trees, a crevasse field or a cliff.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eterrain trap\u003C\/a\u003E. LARGE (\u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/d2\u0022 title=\u0022Could bury, injure, or kill a person.\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003ED2\u003C\/a\u003E) \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eavalanches\u003C\/a\u003E could bury, injure or kill a person. VERY LARGE (\u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/d3\u0022 title=\u0022Could bury and destroy a car, damage a truck, destroy a wood frame house, or break a few trees.\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003ED3\u003C\/a\u003E) \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eavalanches\u003C\/a\u003E could bury cars, destroy a house, or break trees. HISTORIC (\u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/d4\u0022 title=\u0022Could destroy a railway car, large truck, several buildings, or a substantial amount of forest.\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003ED4\u003C\/a\u003E \u0026amp;\u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/d5\u0022 title=\u0022Could gouge the landscape. Largest snow avalanche known.\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003ED5\u003C\/a\u003E) \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eavalanches\u003C\/a\u003E are even more destructive, nearing the maximum size the slope could produce and could destroy all or part of a small town.\u003C\/p\u003E\n ","list":["trigger","shrinkToFit"]},"beautytips_manager_custom_8":{"cssSelect":"span#trend-info","style":"default","trigger":["click","click"],"shrinkToFit":false,"ajaxDisableLink":false,"text":" \u003Cp\u003ETrend of snowpack instability and subsequent \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eavalanche\u003C\/a\u003E danger for this specific \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eavalanche\u003C\/a\u003E problem over the next 24 hours. There are three different possible trends: increasing danger, same danger, or decreasing danger.\u003C\/p\u003E\n ","list":["trigger","shrinkToFit"]},"beautytips_manager_custom_9":{"cssSelect":"span#problem-rose-info","style":"default","trigger":["click","click"],"shrinkToFit":false,"ajaxDisableLink":false,"text":" \u003Cp\u003EThe \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/aspect\u0022 title=\u0022The compass direction a slope faces (i.e. North, South, East, or West.)\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003EAspect\u003C\/a\u003E\/Elevation diagram describes the spatial pattern of the \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003EAvalanche\u003C\/a\u003E Problem by \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/aspect\u0022 title=\u0022The compass direction a slope faces (i.e. North, South, East, or West.)\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Easpect\u003C\/a\u003E (the direction a slope faces) and elevation band (Above, Near, or Below Treeline). The diagram will be filled with blue where the \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003EAvalanche\u003C\/a\u003E Problem exists. You can view the diagram as you would a mountain on a topographic map. The outer ring represents the Below Treeline elevation band, middle ring Near Treeline, and the inner ring Above Treeline. The diagram is oriented like a compass, with the top wedges representing north \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/aspect\u0022 title=\u0022The compass direction a slope faces (i.e. North, South, East, or West.)\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Easpects\u003C\/a\u003E, the left wedges representing west, etc.\u003C\/p\u003E\n ","list":["trigger","shrinkToFit"]},"beautytips_manager_custom_10":{"cssSelect":"span#avalanche-danger-scale-info","style":"default","trigger":["click","click"],"shrinkToFit":false,"ajaxDisableLink":false,"text":" \u003Cp\u003EThe North American \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003EAvalanche\u003C\/a\u003E Danger Scale is a five level scale used to communicate the danger of \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eavalanche\u003C\/a\u003E to backcountry recreationalists. The danger is a combination of the expected likelihood, size, and distribution of \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eavalanches\u003C\/a\u003E. It provides a very basic description of the \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eavalanche\u003C\/a\u003E conditions. <div id="position" class="Public">
	<strong>Observation made by: </strong>Public</div>
<div class='obs-pages'><div class="field-group-htabs-wrapper"><h2 class="element-invisible">Tabs</h2><div class="horizontal-tabs-panes"><fieldset class="collapsible collapsed group-quick-obs-dis field-group-htab form-wrapper"><legend><span class="fieldset-legend">Observation</span></legend><div class="fieldset-wrapper"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-above field-wrapper"><div  class="field-label">Description of Snow, Weather, and Avalanche Conditions: </div><div  class="field-items"><div  class="field-item even"><p>Started breaking trail about 5:45 am. A couple hand pits seemed to show a pretty bomber pack. First lap down from the top of flagpole was fantastic, got nothing to move. <br />
	Felt good enough about things that we decided to ski a more aggressive line, typically I would never ski that one the morning after a storm, clearly it was a stupid mistake getting caught up with powder fever a ding to the mix temps where already warming rapidly at 9:35 when this slid occurred.</p>
<p>Within a few turns down the nose it broke on me on about a 1 foot deep storm slab. I was able to almost ski out of it but did get carried a short ways before I was able to self arrest. </p>
<p>I had forgot got my radio and was not able to call up that I was ok. My partner could only see the run out far below and assumed I had been carried all the way down as it rolls over steeply. While coming down he released another pocket of snow, I saw it barreling down towards me, I augured in best that I could put my head down hoping it would just go over me but it sent me tumbling head over heals until I was able to arrest again.</p>
<p>In the second tumble I lost a ski that went pretty much to the end of the slid which was pretty big. They did a beacon search on the way down as the slide took out part of the skin track. </p>
<p>Ski was recovered and my partners skinned it back up to me.</p>
<p>lots of lessons to be learned today</p>
<p> </p>
<p> </p>
<p> </p>
</div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-ob-snowpit-photo field-type-image field-label-above field-wrapper"><div  class="field-label">Snowpit or crown profile photo or graph: </div><div        <div class="field field-name-field-is-this-an-avalanche-obser field-type-list-boolean field-label-above field-wrapper"><div  class="field-label">Is this an Avalanche Observation?: </div><div  class="field-items"><div  class="field-item even">Yes</div></div></div>       <br>
       <br>
       <div class="field field-name-field-conditions-alerts-tax-term field-type-taxonomy-term-reference field-label-above field-wrapper clearfix"><h3 class="field-label">Conditions Alerts: </h3><ul class="links"><li class="taxonomy-term-reference-0" class="field-item even"><span class="lineage-item lineage-item-level-0">Avalanche Activity</span></li><li class="taxonomy-term-reference-1" class="field-item even odd"><span class="lineage-item lineage-item-level-0">Recent Loading</span></li><li class="taxonomy-term-reference-2" class="field-item even odd even"><span class="lineage-item lineage-item-level-0">Recent Loading</span><span class="hierarchical-select-item-separator">›</span><span class="lineage-item lineage-item-level-1">Blowing Snow</span></li></ul></div><br>
       <div class="field field-name-field-terrain-alerts field-type-list-text field-label-above field-wrapper"><div  class="field-label">Terrain Alerts: </div><div  class="field-items"><div  class="field-item even">Slopes Steeper than 30 degrees</div><div  class="field-item even odd">Obvious Slide Path</div><div  class="field-item even odd even">Trigger Points</div><div  class="field-item even odd even odd">Terrain Traps</div><div  class="field-item even odd even odd even">Terrain Matches the Advisory</div></div></div><br>
   </td>
 </tr>
</table>
<div id="position" class="Public">
	<strong>Observation made by: </strong>Public</div>
<div class='obs-pages'><div class="field-group-htabs-wrapper"><h2 class="element-invisible">Tabs</h2><div class="horizontal-tabs-panes"><fieldset class="collapsible collapsed group-quick-obs-dis field-group-htab form-wrapper"><legend><span class="fieldset-legend">Observation</span></legend><div class="fieldset-wrapper"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-above field-wrapper"><div  class="field-label">Description of Snow, Weather, and Avalanche Conditions: </div><div  class="field-items"><div  class="field-item even"><p>Upon arriving at the Jake's parking areas there was some new avalanche activity on the upper mountain visible from the road.  Other groups skiing in the area stated that two separate skiers had triggered wind slabs avalanches up to 12" in depth on an open section of the East Bowl near treeline (NTL).  They additionally stated that at least one skier had been caught and carried in the avalanche but was unharmed only losing a ski.  </p>
<p>Skiing Jake's this morning found good powdery conditions in the morning that consolidated as the day progressed. We found Moderate winds blowing snow loading wind slabs near ridgetops through the entirety of the day.  Loading was most predominately on NE-E-SE facing slope.  </p>
<p>We were able to get multiple isolated pocket slabs (perhaps lingering storm slabs) up to 20m in width and up 4 to 6 inches in depth to release in steeper terrain and convex rollovers well below treeline and above 7,500 feet.</p>
</div></div></div><div class="slick slick--colorbox slick--less slick--skin--classic slick--optionset--slide-carousel-bar unslick" id="slick-node-12862-observation-field-snowpack-avalanche-weather-1">
  
          <div class="slick__slide slide slide--0 slide--caption--below">                  <a href="https://www.sierraavalanchecenter.org/sites/default/files/obs-img/202102031639-img_20210203_163407.jpg" class="slick__colorbox litebox" data-media="{"type":"image"}"><div class="media media--image media--switch media--loading" data-thumb="https://www.sierraavalanchecenter.org/sites/default/files/styles/small_thumb/public/obs-img/202102031639-img_20210203_163407.jpg?itok=sJGj9e3J"><img height="2048" width="1536" alt="Avalanche on the east face of Jake's as seen from the road." title="" class="media__image media__element lazy" src="data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIAAAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAAALAAAAAABAAEAAAIBRAA7" data-lazy="https://www.sierraavalanchecenter.org/sites/default/files/styles/large/public/obs-img/202102031639-img_20210203_163407.jpg?itok=zPWgy3pE" /></div><span class="media-icon media-icon--lightbox media-icon--colorbox"></span></a><div class="litebox-caption element-invisible">Avalanche on the east face of Jake's as seen from the road.</div>            
      
      </div>    
  </div>

       <div class="field field-name-field-conditions-alerts-tax-term field-type-taxonomy-term-reference field-label-above field-wrapper clearfix"><h3 class="field-label">Conditions Alerts: </h3><ul class="links"><li class="taxonomy-term-reference-0" class="field-item even"><span class="lineage-item lineage-item-level-0">Avalanche Activity</span></li></ul></div><br>

<div id="position" class="Public">
	<strong>Observation made by: </strong>Public</div>
<div class='obs-pages'><div class="field-group-htabs-wrapper"><h2 class="element-invisible">Tabs</h2><div class="horizontal-tabs-panes"><fieldset class="collapsible collapsed group-quick-obs-dis field-group-htab form-wrapper"><legend><span class="fieldset-legend">Observation</span></legend><div class="fieldset-wrapper"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-above field-wrapper"><div  class="field-label">Description of Snow, Weather, and Avalanche Conditions: </div><div  class="field-items"><div  class="field-item even"><p>Two skiers climbing on opposite sides of the bowl one skier was standing on the red X triggered a sizable slab with lots of energy  he was carried all the way to the bottom into the trees he deployed his airbag and his head was barely underneath the surface of the snow The other skier was out of the path of the avalanche. No injuries. </p>
</div></div></div><div class="slick slick--colorbox slick--less slick--skin--classic slick--optionset--slide-carousel-bar unslick" id="slick-node-12552-observation-field-snowpack-avalanche-weather-1">

<div id="position" class="Public">
	<strong>Observation made by: </strong>Public</div>
<div class='obs-pages'><div class="field-group-htabs-wrapper"><h2 class="element-invisible">Tabs</h2><div class="horizontal-tabs-panes"><fieldset class="collapsible collapsed group-quick-obs-dis field-group-htab form-wrapper"><legend><span class="fieldset-legend">Observation</span></legend><div class="fieldset-wrapper"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-above field-wrapper"><div  class="field-label">Description of Snow, Weather, and Avalanche Conditions: </div><div  class="field-items"><div  class="field-item even"><p>During our ride today we ran into some other riders we knew near bear valley out little truckee summit staging area. It was around 12:30.  They told us of another group of riders who we knew, that had been involved in an avalanche. They said 1 rider triggered it, was caught and partially buried.  <br />
	 </p>
<p>we then rode up to where the avalanche happened. It was at 7800' on a NE aspect, a convex roll that was heavily wind loaded.  the start zone was between 38 and 42 degrees. From crown to toe it was about 280ft with a width of around 100ft. Snowmobile size debris chunks along with the debris being from 4-6' deep. <br />
	 </p>
<p>I inspected the crown, that was 6' tall, it was one cohesive wind slab. It failed on the new old snow interface. I dug down below the bed surface and found the dec 11 facets below the bed surface. This avalanche did not step down to that layer. <br />
	 </p>
<p>After our ride I called the person involved and spoke with him about the incident. He said his group was aware of the advisory, they were riding smart and not exposing more than one at a time and staying off slopes over 30 degrees. But he came out of the trees on a side hill and was suddenly on this slope and terrain feature, he knew right away it was a bad spot then it fractured. It sounded like he tried to out run it but with the trees he had to slow down. That's when it hit him and separated him from his sled. He was burried up to his chest I believe. And his machine was fully burried. <br />
	 </p>
<p>earlier in our day we noticed some cracking in the new snow, but only near another snowmobile track that made the section of snow unsupported. Lots of wind transport evidence, and plenty of fresh powder.  </p>
</div></div></div><div class="slick slick--colorbox slick--skin--classic slick--optionset--slide-carousel-bar" id="slick-node-12559-observation-field-snowpack-avalanche-weather-1">

\u003Cp\u003EAbove Treeline is the highest of the three elevation bands used in the SAC advisories. It includes alpine areas where the most snow falls and the winds are the strongest. It is not an exact elevation, but a characteristic of the terrain, beginning as the treeline transitions into open slopes extending to ridges and the tops of the highest peaks.\u003C\/p\u003E\n ","list":["trigger","shrinkToFit"]},"beautytips_manager_custom_4":{"cssSelect":"p#mid-rating-info","style":"default","trigger":["click","click"],"shrinkToFit":false,"ajaxDisableLink":false,"text":" \u003Cp\u003ENear Treeline is the middle of the three elevation bands used in the SAC advisories. It is a transition zone between dense forests and treeless alpine areas. It is the narrowest of the three elevation bands, extending only a few hundred feet above and below the treeline. It varies locally, and is not a constant elevation or width.\u003C\/p\u003E\n ","list":["trigger","shrinkToFit"]},"beautytips_manager_custom_5":{"cssSelect":"p#lower-rating-info","style":"default","trigger":["click","click"],"shrinkToFit":false,"ajaxDisableLink":false,"text":" \u003Cp\u003EBelow Treeline is the lowest of three elevation bands used in the SAC advisories. It extends from valley floors or snowline to Near Treeline. Open areas and sparse trees are possible. Snowfall tends to be less than the other elevation bands. Tree cover shelters the snow from wind effects.\u003C\/p\u003E\n ","list":["trigger","shrinkToFit"]},"beautytips_manager_custom_6":{"cssSelect":"span#likelihood-info","style":"default","trigger":["click","click"],"shrinkToFit":false,"ajaxDisableLink":false,"text":" \u003Cp\u003ELikelihood is a description of the chance of encountering a particular \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eavalanche\u003C\/a\u003E problem. It combines the spatial distribution of the problem and the sensitivity or ease of triggering an \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eavalanche\u003C\/a\u003E. The spatial distribution indicates how likely you are to encounter the problem in the highlighted \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eavalanche\u003C\/a\u003E terrain. The sensitive indicates how easy it is to \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/trigger\u0022 title=\u0022A disturbance that initiates fracture within the weak layer causing an avalanche. In 90 percent of avalanche accidents, the victim or someone in the victims party triggers the avalanche.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Etrigger\u003C\/a\u003E \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eavalanches\u003C\/a\u003E when you do encounter them. Sensitivity includes both natural or spontaneous release and human \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/trigger\u0022 title=\u0022A disturbance that initiates fracture within the weak layer causing an avalanche. In 90 percent of avalanche accidents, the victim or someone in the victims party triggers the avalanche.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Etriggered\u003C\/a\u003E \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eavalanches\u003C\/a\u003E.\u003C\/p\u003E\n ","list":["trigger","shrinkToFit"]},"beautytips_manager_custom_7":{"cssSelect":"span#size-info","style":"default","trigger":["click","click"],"shrinkToFit":false,"ajaxDisableLink":false,"text":" \u003Cp\u003ESize is based on the destructive potential of \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eavalanches\u003C\/a\u003E. SMALL (\u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/d1\u0022 title=\u0022Relatively harmless to people.\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003ED1\u003C\/a\u003E) \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eavalanches\u003C\/a\u003E are relatively harmless to people unless they push you into a \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/terrain-trap\u0022 title=\u0022Terrain in which the consequences of an avalanche are especially hazardous, such as a gully, an abrupt transition, an avalanche path that terminates in trees, a crevasse field or a cliff.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eterrain trap\u003C\/a\u003E. LARGE (\u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/d2\u0022 title=\u0022Could bury, injure, or kill a person.\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003ED2\u003C\/a\u003E) \u003Ca href=\u0022\/avalanche-terms\/avalanche\u0022 title=\u0022A mass of snow sliding, tumbling, or flowing down an inclined surface.\r\n\u0022 class=\u0022lexicon-term\u0022\u003Eavalanches\u003C\/a\u003E could bury, injure or kill a person. <div class='obs-pages'><div class="field-group-htabs-wrapper"><h2 class="element-invisible">Tabs</h2><div class="horizontal-tabs-panes"><fieldset class="collapsible collapsed group-quick-obs-dis field-group-htab form-wrapper"><legend><span class="fieldset-legend">Observation</span></legend><div class="fieldset-wrapper"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-above field-wrapper"><div  class="field-label">Description of Snow, Weather, and Avalanche Conditions: </div><div  class="field-items"><div  class="field-item even"><p>We came up on a avalanche incident around 12:10pm near Tom's meadow,  bear meadow area. A sledder triggered an avalanche on a wind loaded slope. He was buried up to his chin. We showed up about two hours after the incident occurred, according to the crew involved. <br />
	 </p>
<p>  About 400 yards before we saw the avalanche we observed large shooting cracks on the exact same slope/aspect/cornice </p>

\u003Cp\u003EAbove Treeline is the highest of the three elevation bands used in the SAC advisories. It includes alpine areas where the most snow falls and the winds are the strongest. It is not an exact elevation, but a characteristic of the terrain, beginning as the treeline transitions into open slopes extending to ridges and the tops of the highest peaks.\u003C\/p\u003E\n ","list":["trigger","shrinkToFit"]},"beautytips_manager_custom_4":{"cssSelect":"p#mid-rating-info","style":"default","trigger":["click","click"],"shrinkToFit":false,"ajaxDisableLink":false,"text":" \u003Cp\u003ENear Treeline is the middle of the three elevation bands used in the SAC advisories. <div id="position" class="Public">
	<strong>Observation made by: </strong>Public</div>
<div class='obs-pages'><div class="field-group-htabs-wrapper"><h2 class="element-invisible">Tabs</h2><div class="horizontal-tabs-panes"><fieldset class="collapsible collapsed group-quick-obs-dis field-group-htab form-wrapper"><legend><span class="fieldset-legend">Observation</span></legend><div class="fieldset-wrapper"><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-above field-wrapper"><div  class="field-label">Description of Snow, Weather, and Avalanche Conditions: </div><div  class="field-items"><div  class="field-item even"><p>Our group was cognizant of the avalanche forecast, had been doing observations, planning our routes, communicating as we made progress and terrain changed, etc.  </p>
<p>As we were working around the basin to get into Webber Lake, we were re-routed due to wind scowered ridges and exposed rock.</p>
<p>We were side-hilling and in a momentary lapse of judgement, or the fact that we were just moving along too fast, I popped out of the trees onto an exposed face.  I immediately recognized the hazard, but immediately saw the fsnow racture abiove me and propegate across the ridge.  </p>
<p>I attempted to outrun the slide as I had no other choice, but as I hit the tree line below (and associated terrain traps), was caught, thrown from the sled into a tree stand, and buried up to my helmet.</p>
<p>Once the snow came to a stop I was able to break the snow free around my face/head, then radioed my friends (who witnessed the whole thing from above and had me generally marked).  They were able to respond within 1 minute and free me from the pit.</p>
<p>I was un-injured, and was able to recover my sled which was buried ~6 feet deep.</p>
</div></div></div><div class="slick slick--colorbox slick--skin--classic slick--optionset--slide-carousel-bar" id="slick-node-12556-observation-field-snowpack-avalanche-weather-1">
